options: Sperm competition selects for: (1) larger testes relative to body size (chimpanzees with multi-male mating have testes ~3x larger relative to body size than gorillas with single-male groups), (2) higher sperm counts and faster-swimming sperm, (3) copulatory plugs that block subsequent males' sperm access, (4) mate-guarding behavior to prevent rivals from mating, and (5) sperm removal mechanisms (dragonfly penises have backward-facing spines that scoop out rival sperm before depositing their own)
Sperm competition has no effect on male reproductive anatomy or behavior
Sperm competition occurs only in aquatic organisms with external fertilization
The sole adaptation to sperm competition is increased body size
questions.explanation: Sperm competition (Parker 1970) is a powerful selective force shaping male reproductive biology. Adaptations are diverse: (1) Testis size: Across primates, relative testis size correlates with mating system. Chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes), where females mate with multiple males in quick succession, have very large testes (~0.3% body mass). Gorillas (Gorilla gorilla), where a single silverback monopolizes mating, have small testes (~0.02% body mass). Humans are intermediate. (2) Sperm quantity and quality: Species with intense sperm competition produce more sperm per ejaculate, with higher motility. Passerine birds with higher extra-pair paternity rates have faster-swimming sperm. (3) Seminal fluid proteins: In Drosophila, over 100 accessory gland proteins (Acps) manipulate female physiology — increasing egg-laying, reducing remating receptivity, and displacing previous males' sperm. These proteins evolve rapidly under positive selection. (4) Copulatory plugs: Rodents, many insects, and some primates deposit plugs that physically block subsequent males' sperm. Plug size correlates with sperm competition intensity across rodent species. (5) Sperm removal: Male dragonflies (Calopteryx) have penile structures that physically remove stored sperm from previous matings before depositing their own — the last-male sperm precedence mechanism. (6) Mate guarding: Post-copulatory mate guarding (staying with the female during her fertile period) is common in birds, insects, and primates. (7) Strategic ejaculate allocation: Males adjust ejaculate size based on perceived sperm competition risk (larger ejaculates when a rival male is present).

questions.question: Parent-offspring conflict (Trivers, 1974) predicts that parents and offspring will disagree over the amount of parental investment. Why does this conflict arise?
options: Because an offspring is related to itself by r = 1 but to its siblings by only r = 0.5 (full siblings), each offspring is selected to demand more investment than the parent is selected to give — the parent, equally related to all its offspring (r = 0.5 each), maximizes fitness by distributing investment among current and future offspring; the offspring benefits from extra investment until the cost to the parent's other offspring (weighted by r = 0.5) exceeds the benefit to itself
Parents and offspring always agree on the optimal level of investment
Parent-offspring conflict exists only in species with exactly two offspring
The conflict arises because offspring want less food, not more
questions.explanation: Robert Trivers (1974) identified a fundamental genetic asymmetry between parent and offspring interests. The logic: (1) From the offspring's perspective: It values itself at r = 1 (it is 100% related to itself) but values each full sibling at r = 0.5. Therefore, an offspring 'wants' more investment from the parent than the parent should optimally provide, because the offspring discounts the cost to siblings by half. (2) From the parent's perspective: The parent is equally related to all offspring (r = 0.5) and maximizes inclusive fitness by allocating investment to produce the greatest total number of surviving offspring. This means weaning the current offspring when the marginal benefit of continued investment is less than the benefit of investing in future offspring. (3) The zone of conflict: When the cost-to-benefit ratio of parental investment (measured in lost future siblings) is between 1 (where the offspring wants to stop) and 2 (where the parent wants to stop — because the offspring weights sibling cost at 0.5). In this zone, additional investment benefits the offspring but reduces the parent's overall fitness. Evidence: (a) Weaning conflict in mammals — offspring cry, beg, and resist weaning; mothers push them away. (b) Sibling rivalry — siblicide in eagles, pelicans, and boobies (first-hatched chick kills younger sibling). (c) Begging behavior in birds — offspring beg more than is honest, escalating when hungrier. (d) Genomic imprinting — paternally expressed genes (e.g., IGF2) promote fetal growth, while maternally expressed genes (e.g., IGF2R) restrict it, reflecting parent-of-origin conflict over resource extraction from the mother.

questions.question: Social learning and cultural transmission allow behaviors to spread through populations without genetic change. What is a well-documented example of animal culture?
options: Japanese macaques (Macaca fuscata) on Koshima Island developed sweet potato washing behavior (first observed in a juvenile named Imo in 1953), which spread through the troop via social learning over several years — the behavior was transmitted horizontally (peers) and vertically (mother to offspring), demonstrating cultural transmission; similar cultural traditions include tool use in New Caledonian crows, regional song dialects in birds and whales, and chimpanzee tool-use traditions that vary between populations
All animal behavior is genetically determined and cultural transmission does not exist
Social learning occurs only in primates and no other animal groups
Cultural behaviors are always identical across all populations of a species
questions.explanation: Animal culture (Whiten et al. 1999, Laland and Galef 2009) is defined as socially learned behavior that is shared within a population and transmitted across generations. Key examples: (1) Japanese macaques: Imo's innovations on Koshima Island included sweet potato washing (1953) and wheat-sifting (throwing sand-wheat mixtures into water, where wheat floats). These behaviors spread non-randomly — first to Imo's close associates and kin, then gradually through the troop. Young individuals and females adopted the behavior faster than adult males. The pattern of spread (S-shaped diffusion curve, social network-biased) rules out independent invention. (2) Chimpanzees: Whiten et al. (1999) documented 39 behavioral variants across seven long-term study sites that cannot be explained by ecological or genetic differences — representing cultural traditions. Examples: ant-dipping technique (Gombe: short sticks, quick withdrawal; Tai: long sticks, slow withdrawal), nut-cracking (West African populations only), and leaf-grooming. (3) New Caledonian crows: Manufacture hooked stick tools and stepped pandanus-leaf tools with regionally distinct designs (tool traditions). Juvenile crows learn tool techniques from parents over an extended dependency period. (4) Cetaceans: Humpback whale song undergoes progressive cultural evolution — new songs originate in one population and spread across the Pacific over 2-3 years. Killer whale populations have distinct vocal dialects maintained through maternal cultural transmission. (5) Social learning mechanisms: local enhancement (attention drawn to location), stimulus enhancement (attention to object), observational conditioning, imitation (copying the motor pattern), and teaching (active tutoring, rare outside humans but documented in meerkats and ants).

questions.question: Cooperative breeding occurs when non-breeding individuals help raise the offspring of others. What hypotheses explain why helpers help?
options: Multiple hypotheses explain cooperative breeding: (1) kin selection — helpers gain indirect fitness by assisting related breeders (Florida scrub-jays help parents raise siblings, r = 0.5); (2) ecological constraints — independent breeding territories are scarce, making staying as a helper the best available option; (3) benefits of philopatry — helpers gain direct benefits including territory inheritance, improved skills from practice, and augmented group size for predator defense; (4) pay-to-stay — subordinates help as 'rent' to avoid eviction by dominant breeders
Helpers always gain more fitness than breeders
Cooperative breeding occurs only when food is superabundant
Helpers are always forced to help and gain no fitness benefit
questions.explanation: Cooperative breeding (Emlen 1991, Koenig and Dickinson 2004) has evolved independently in >300 bird species and many mammals (meerkats, wolves, naked mole-rats, marmosets). Explanations: (1) Kin selection: Helpers are usually close relatives of the breeders (offspring from previous years in most cooperatively breeding birds). By helping raise siblings (r = 0.5), they gain indirect fitness. Measured in Florida scrub-jays (Woolfenden and Fitzpatrick): helpers increase breeder productivity by ~0.5 extra fledglings per helper. (2) Ecological constraints hypothesis (Emlen 1982): When suitable territories or mates are saturated, floating independently is costly (high mortality, low breeding prospects). Helping while waiting for a territory vacancy yields higher fitness than dispersing into a hostile environment. Supported by: territories created by removing holders are quickly occupied by former helpers; helper frequency increases when habitat is saturated. (3) Benefits of philopatry (Stacey and Ligon 1991): Helpers gain direct benefits: (a) Territory inheritance — helpers may inherit the natal territory when parents die. (b) Skill acquisition — practice at nestling care improves future reproductive competence. (c) Group augmentation — larger groups have lower per-capita predation rates and better territory defense. (4) Pay-to-stay (Gaston 1978, Kokko et al. 2002): Dominant breeders tolerate subordinates only if subordinates contribute to brood care. Experimental evidence in cichlid fish (Neolamprologus pulcher): subordinates that are prevented from helping are evicted by dominants. (5) These hypotheses are not mutually exclusive — multiple factors often operate simultaneously within the same species.

questions.question: Dominance hierarchies organize social groups. What determines an individual's rank, and what are the fitness consequences?
options: Rank is influenced by body size, fighting ability (resource holding potential, RHP), experience, alliances, and in some species maternal rank (spotted hyenas — daughters inherit maternal rank through coalition support); high-ranking individuals typically gain priority access to food and mates (alpha male chimpanzees sire ~30-50% of offspring), but dominance also carries costs including higher stress hormones, greater energy expenditure on aggression, and increased injury risk
Dominance hierarchies are completely random with no relationship to individual traits
Dominant individuals always have lower survival rates than subordinates
Hierarchies exist only in captive populations and do not occur in wild animals
questions.explanation: Dominance hierarchies (Schjelderup-Ebbe 1922, first described peck orders in chickens) are structured social relationships where individuals differ in competitive ability and priority of access to resources. Determinants of rank: (1) Resource holding potential (RHP, Parker 1974): body size, weaponry, fighting experience, and physiological condition. In red deer, larger stags with bigger antlers win contests. (2) Alliances and coalitions: In many primates (baboons, chimpanzees), coalitions between individuals can override individual RHP. An alpha male chimpanzee often maintains position through alliances with other males rather than individual fighting ability. (3) Prior residency: In many species (e.g., territorial fish), prior residents have an advantage ('owner effect'). (4) Maternal rank inheritance: In cercopithecine monkeys and spotted hyenas, daughters achieve ranks just below their mothers through active support from mothers and other high-ranking group members. Youngest daughters rank above older daughters (youngest ascendancy). Fitness consequences of dominance: Benefits: (a) Priority of access to food — dominant baboons and wolves feed first. (b) Mating access — alpha male chimpanzees sire 30-50% of offspring despite comprising <10% of males. (c) Reduced harassment. Costs: (a) Stress — in some species, dominant individuals have chronically elevated cortisol (e.g., alpha male baboons during unstable hierarchies). (b) Energy expenditure on aggression and territory patrol. (c) Injury risk from challenges. Whether dominance is costly or beneficial depends on species and social system: in cooperative species like meerkats, dominant females (who breed) have lower cortisol than subordinates.

questions.question: Researchers studying a population of side-blotched lizards (Uta stansburiana) observe three male morphs: orange-throated (aggressive, maintain large territories), blue-throated (guard small territories with one female), and yellow-throated (mimic females, sneak copulations). Over six years, the most common morph cycles: orange dominates in years 1-2, yellow in years 3-4, blue in years 5-6, then back to orange. What maintains this polymorphism?
options: This is a rock-paper-scissors game driven by negative frequency-dependent selection — orange beats blue (overpowers small territory defenders), yellow beats orange (sneaks into large territories that cannot be fully guarded), and blue beats yellow (closely guards mate, detecting sneakers); each morph has highest fitness when rare and the type it beats is common, creating a non-transitive competitive hierarchy that prevents any morph from fixing in the population
The cycling is caused by random genetic drift with no selective explanation
Environmental temperature fluctuations cause the color changes within individual lizards
All three morphs have identical fitness at all frequencies
questions.explanation: Sinervo and Lively's (1996) study of side-blotched lizards is one of the best documented examples of evolutionary game dynamics in nature. The system: Three genetically determined male throat-color morphs exhibit a non-transitive (rock-paper-scissors) competitive hierarchy: (1) Orange-throated males: Ultra-aggressive, maintain large territories encompassing multiple females. High testosterone levels drive their territorial aggression. They overpower blue males by usurping their small territories. Orange > Blue. (2) Yellow-throated males: Non-territorial, female-mimicking sneakers. Their small size and female coloration allow them to infiltrate the large territories of orange males without being detected. They cannot invade blue male territories because blue males stay close to their single mate. Yellow > Orange. (3) Blue-throated males: Form pair bonds, defend small territories with a single female, and guard their mate closely. Their vigilance allows them to detect and repel yellow sneakers. Blue > Yellow. Frequency-dependent dynamics: When orange is common (has beaten blue), yellow invades (beats orange). When yellow is common, blue invades (beats yellow). When blue is common, orange invades (beats blue). This creates an approximately 6-year cycle in morph frequencies. The genetics: Throat color is determined by alleles at the OBY locus, with orange (o) dominant to blue (b), and yellow (y) a third allele. This system demonstrates: (a) Evolutionary game theory in action (mixed ESS through cycling rather than stable equilibrium). (b) Negative frequency-dependent selection maintaining genetic polymorphism. (c) Alternative reproductive strategies as an ESS. (d) The power of non-transitive competitive interactions (no single 'best' strategy).

questions.question: Group living provides benefits but also imposes costs. What is the dilution effect, and how does it relate to the selfish herd?
options: The dilution effect predicts that an individual's risk of being taken by a predator decreases as group size increases (probability = 1/N for N group members) — Hamilton's selfish herd theory (1971) extends this by predicting that individuals should minimize their 'domain of danger' (the area closer to them than to any other group member) by moving toward the center of the group, producing the characteristic tight aggregations seen in fish schools, bird flocks, and ungulate herds, where peripheral individuals suffer disproportionately higher predation
Living in groups always increases individual predation risk
The dilution effect states that group living dilutes food resources evenly among members
The selfish herd refers to group selection for cooperative defense
questions.explanation: Group living anti-predator benefits involve several overlapping mechanisms: (1) Dilution effect (Foster and Treherne 1981): If a predator attacks a group and takes one individual, each individual's probability of being the victim decreases as 1/N (where N = group size). This provides a passive benefit of grouping even without any cooperative vigilance. It selects for grouping when predator attack rate does not increase proportionally with group size. (2) Selfish herd (Hamilton 1971): Hamilton proposed that prey aggregate not for the good of the group but because each individual selfishly tries to place others between itself and approaching predators. Formally, each individual minimizes its 'domain of danger' — the Voronoi polygon defined as the area closer to that individual than to any neighbor. Central individuals have smaller domains of danger than peripheral ones. This produces: (a) Tight aggregation — individuals pack closely together. (b) Central-marginal gradient — predation risk is higher at group edges. Field evidence: muskox in circular formations with calves in center, pelicans attacked on the periphery of flocks. (3) Many-eyes effect (Pulliam 1973): In larger groups, each individual can spend less time vigilant (scanning for predators) and more time foraging because the collective detection probability is higher. This creates a tension with scramble competition for food. (4) Confusion effect: Predators have difficulty targeting a single individual in a fast-moving group (starling murmurations, fish schools). Oddity effect — unusual individuals in a group are targeted preferentially. Costs of group living: (a) Increased competition for food (scramble and interference). (b) Higher parasite and disease transmission. (c) Increased conspicuousness to predators. (d) Reproductive suppression in subordinates. The optimal group size balances these costs and benefits.

questions.question: The optimal diet model predicts which food items a forager should include in its diet. What does the model predict about when a forager should specialize versus generalize?
options: The optimal diet model (Stephens and Krebs, 1986) predicts that a forager should include a food type in its diet based on its profitability (energy/handling time) and the encounter rate with higher-ranked items — a prey type should be included only when the rate of encountering more profitable items is low enough that the overall intake rate is improved by including it; critically, whether to include a food type depends only on the encounter rate with better items, NOT on the abundance of the item itself
Animals should always eat every food item they encounter
Specialization is always better than generalization regardless of prey abundance
Diet choice is random and does not follow any optimality rules
questions.explanation: The optimal diet model (also called the prey model or diet breadth model) from optimal foraging theory makes precise, testable predictions: Assumptions: (1) The forager encounters prey items sequentially and randomly. (2) Each prey type i has energy content (e_i), handling time (h_i), and encounter rate (λ_i). (3) Prey types are ranked by profitability: e_i / h_i. (4) The forager should maximize the long-term rate of energy intake (E/T). Decision rule: Always eat the most profitable prey type (rank 1). Add the next-ranked prey type to the diet if: λ₁ × e₁ / (1 + λ₁ × h₁) < (λ₁ × e₁ + λ₂ × e₂) / (1 + λ₁ × h₁ + λ₂ × h₂). Key predictions: (a) Zero-one rule — each prey type is either always included or always excluded (no partial preferences). (b) Inclusion depends on the encounter rate with higher-ranked items, NOT on the item's own abundance. If high-rank prey are abundant, the forager should specialize; if rare, the forager should generalize. (c) As high-rank prey become more abundant, low-rank items are dropped from the diet. (d) Adding a new high-rank prey type causes specialization; removing it causes generalization. Experimental support: Shore crabs select mussels of optimal size (maximum profitability); great tits switch from generalist to specialist when large prey encounter rates increase. Violations reveal important factors the model excludes: nutrient constraints (herbivores need mixed diets), predation risk while handling prey, and incomplete information about prey distributions.

questions.question:
Match the following pioneer researchers with their key contributions to animal behavior:
(I) Konrad Lorenz
(II) Karl von Frisch
(III) Nikolaas Tinbergen
(IV) E.O. Wilson

(P) Decoded the symbolic communication system of the honeybee waggle dance, demonstrating that bees convey distance and direction to food sources
(Q) Founded sociobiology with a comprehensive synthesis applying evolutionary theory to social behavior across all animals, including controversial extension to humans
(R) Proposed four complementary questions for analyzing behavior (causation, development, function, phylogeny) and conducted pioneering experiments on sign stimuli and supernormal stimuli
(S) Described imprinting in greylag geese, formalized the concept of fixed action patterns and innate releasing mechanisms, and championed the instinct-learning interaction
options: I-S, II-P, III-R, IV-Q
I-R, II-Q, III-P, IV-S
I-P, II-S, III-Q, IV-R
I-Q, II-R, III-S, IV-P
questions.explanation: Konrad Lorenz (I-S): Austrian ethologist (Nobel Prize 1973). Described filial imprinting in greylag geese — young goslings form attachments to the first moving object seen during a critical period. Formalized the concept of FAPs (fixed action patterns) triggered by IRMs (innate releasing mechanisms) responding to sign stimuli. Developed the hydraulic model of motivation (now largely abandoned). Key works: 'King Solomon's Ring' (1949), 'On Aggression' (1963). Karl von Frisch (II-P): German-Austrian ethologist (Nobel Prize 1973). Decoded the honeybee dance language: round dance (food nearby) and waggle dance (food far away), with dance angle encoding direction relative to sun and waggle duration encoding distance. Also discovered bee color vision and ultraviolet sensitivity, and demonstrated that bees use polarized light for navigation. Nikolaas Tinbergen (III-R): Dutch ethologist (Nobel Prize 1973). Proposed four questions/levels of analysis (1963): causation, ontogeny, function, phylogeny. Conducted elegant experiments: showed that stickleback territorial aggression is triggered by red coloration (sign stimulus), that supernormal stimuli (exaggerated eggs) are preferred over normal stimuli (herring gulls), and elucidated the function of eggshell removal behavior through fitness experiments. Key work: 'The Study of Instinct' (1951). E.O. Wilson (IV-Q): American biologist. Published 'Sociobiology: The New Synthesis' (1975), applying evolutionary principles to social behavior across animal taxa. The final chapter extending sociobiology to humans generated enormous controversy. Also authored 'On Human Nature' (1978, Pulitzer Prize) and 'The Insect Societies' (1971). Wilson later became a controversial advocate for group selection with David Sloan Wilson.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether migratory birds use a magnetic compass for orientation. What experimental approach would definitively test this hypothesis?
options: Track bird migration routes using GPS loggers without any experimental manipulation

Place migratory birds in Emlen funnel orientation cages during the migratory season and expose them to manipulated magnetic fields using Helmholtz coils — by rotating the magnetic field direction (e.g., shifting magnetic north to geographic east), the researcher predicts the birds' preferred orientation direction will shift correspondingly; include controls with Earth's natural field and test birds under different light conditions, since the avian magnetic compass is light-dependent (requires short-wavelength light through cryptochrome-based radical pair mechanism in the retina)
Observe whether birds migrate in cloudy weather (when they cannot see the sun or stars)
Compare migration timing between different bird species
questions.explanation: The gold standard for testing magnetic compass orientation uses Emlen funnels and manipulated magnetic fields. Experimental design: (1) Emlen funnel: A cone-shaped cage with an ink pad at the bottom and paper lining the sloped walls. When a migratory bird in nocturnal migratory restlessness (Zugunruhe) jumps in its preferred direction, its inked feet leave marks on the paper, recording its directional preference without the bird leaving the cage. (2) Helmholtz coil apparatus: Three pairs of coils arranged orthogonally create a uniform artificial magnetic field whose direction and intensity can be precisely controlled independently of Earth's field. (3) Critical manipulation: Rotate the magnetic field direction while keeping all other cues constant (use indoors, control light, block celestial cues). If birds reorient with the shifted field, magnetic compass use is confirmed. Wolfgang Wiltschko (1968) demonstrated this in European robins: when magnetic north was shifted 120° counterclockwise, the birds' preferred direction shifted accordingly. (4) Light-dependency tests: The avian magnetic compass requires short-wavelength (blue-green) light. Under red light (>630 nm), birds cannot orient magnetically, consistent with the cryptochrome radical-pair mechanism in the retina where flavin-tryptophan radical pairs are sensitive to magnetic field direction only when excited by blue/green photons. (5) Radiofrequency disruption: Oscillating magnetic fields in the MHz range (broadband noise) disrupt the radical-pair mechanism, abolishing magnetic orientation (Ritz et al. 2004). This distinguishes the radical-pair compass from a magnetite-based compass (which is not disrupted by RF). Controls: natural magnetic field (positive control), zero field (negative control), and sham-manipulated coils (powered but producing no field shift).

questions.question: The ideal free distribution (IFD) predicts how foragers distribute themselves among patches of different quality. What does the model predict?
options: The IFD (Fretwell and Lucas, 1970) predicts that animals will distribute themselves among habitat patches such that all individuals achieve equal fitness — more individuals will aggregate in richer patches, but the per-capita intake rate will be equalized across patches because of density-dependent competition; the ratio of foragers in each patch should match the ratio of resource input rates
All foragers should crowd into the single best patch regardless of competition
Foragers should distribute themselves equally among all patches regardless of quality
Only dominant individuals should forage in high-quality patches
questions.explanation: The ideal free distribution (Fretwell and Lucas 1970) is a foundational model in behavioral ecology predicting habitat selection. Assumptions: (1) Ideal — all individuals have complete information about patch qualities and their own fitness in each patch. (2) Free — all individuals are free to move between patches (no despotic exclusion or travel costs). (3) Equal competitors — all individuals are competitively equal. (4) Fitness in a patch decreases with increasing competitor density (density-dependent competition). Prediction: At equilibrium, individuals distribute themselves such that fitness is equalized across all occupied patches. This means: (a) Richer patches attract more individuals, but density-dependent competition reduces per-capita intake. (b) The proportion of individuals in each patch matches the proportion of total resources (input matching). (c) No individual can improve its fitness by moving to another patch (Nash equilibrium). Experimental tests: Milinski (1979) tested IFD with sticklebacks in a tank with two feeding stations delivering Daphnia at different rates (2:1 ratio). Fish distributed themselves approximately 2:1, matching the input ratio. Deviations from IFD: (a) Ideal despotic distribution — dominant individuals exclude subordinates from best patches. (b) Perceptual constraints — animals have incomplete information. (c) Travel costs — moving between patches is not free. (d) Interference competition — aggressive interactions reduce intake in crowded patches more than expected. (e) Unequal competitors — better competitors achieve higher intake in all patches, while poorer competitors are pushed to inferior patches.

questions.question: Sensory exploitation (sensory bias) is a hypothesis for the evolution of female mate preferences. What does this hypothesis propose?
options: Sensory exploitation proposes that male ornamental traits evolve to exploit pre-existing sensory biases in females that originally evolved in non-mating contexts — for example, female water mites (Neumania papillator) are attracted to vibrations resembling their copepod prey, and males evolved to produce similar vibrations during courtship; female swordtail fish (Xiphophorus) prefer males with elongated tail swords, but the preference exists even in species that lack the sword, suggesting the preference predates the trait
Males evolve ornaments that create entirely new sensory preferences in females
Female preferences are always genetically linked to the male trait they prefer
Sensory exploitation only occurs in aquatic organisms
questions.explanation: The sensory exploitation hypothesis (Ryan 1990, Endler and Basolo 1998) proposes that female preferences evolve first (for ecological reasons such as foraging, predator avoidance, or species recognition) and male traits subsequently evolve to exploit these pre-existing biases. Key evidence: (1) Water mites (Neumania papillator): Females are predators of copepods and detect prey by vibrations in the water. Males court females by producing vibrations mimicking copepod swimming movements — 'trembling' their legs at frequencies similar to copepod prey. Proctor (1991) showed that females approach male courtship vibrations because they are initially perceived as prey signals. The male trait exploits the female's foraging sensory system. (2) Swordtail fish (Xiphophorus): Males of some species have elongated caudal fin extensions (swords). Females prefer males with swords. Critically, females of Priapella olmecae (a related species whose males have NEVER had swords) also prefer males with experimentally attached artificial swords (Basolo 1990, 1995). This demonstrates that the preference evolved before the trait — phylogenetic analysis confirms the preference is ancestral and the sword is derived. (3) Tungara frogs (Engystomops pustulosus): Males produce complex calls with a 'whine' (species recognition) plus optional 'chucks.' Females prefer calls with chucks. The chuck stimulates the basilar papilla (BP) of the inner ear, which is tuned to low frequencies for general auditory processing. Males evolved the chuck to exploit this pre-existing tuning. (4) Guppies (Poecilia reticulata): Female preference for orange spots may derive from a foraging preference for orange-colored fruits. The hypothesis differs from Fisherian runaway (where preference and trait coevolve simultaneously) and the good-genes/handicap model (where the preference evolves because it provides fitness information).

questions.question: Brood parasitism is a reproductive strategy where one species lays eggs in the nests of other species. What coevolutionary arms race does this create?
options: Brood parasites (e.g., cuckoos, cowbirds) exploit host parental care — hosts evolve egg recognition and rejection (ejecting foreign eggs or deserting parasitized nests), while parasites counter-evolve increasingly accurate egg mimicry matching host egg color and pattern; the common cuckoo (Cuculus canorus) has evolved host-specific egg morphs (gens) where each female lineage specializes on one host species, with egg mimicry inherited maternally (likely on the W chromosome in this ZW sex-determination system)
Host birds always accept any egg placed in their nest without discrimination
Brood parasitism has no evolutionary effect on host behavior
Parasitic eggs are always larger than host eggs and easily identified
questions.explanation: Obligate brood parasitism in birds provides one of the best-studied examples of coevolutionary arms races (Davies and Brooke 1989, Kilner and Langmore 2011). The parasites: The common cuckoo (Cuculus canorus) lays one egg per host nest, and the cuckoo chick evicts all host eggs/chicks within hours of hatching, monopolizing parental care. Brown-headed cowbirds (Molothrus ater) are generalist parasites using >200 host species. Parasite adaptations: (1) Egg mimicry — cuckoo eggs closely match host eggs in color, pattern, and sometimes size. Each female cuckoo belongs to a 'gens' (host race) specializing on one host species. Since sex is ZW in birds, the mimicry locus is likely W-chromosome linked (passed mother to daughter), maintaining host-specific mimicry despite cross-breeding with males from other gentes. (2) Rapid egg-laying (~10 seconds) and removal of one host egg during parasitism. (3) Short incubation period — cuckoo eggs hatch before host eggs, giving the chick a head start. (4) Chick eviction instinct — innate behavior to push eggs/chicks from the nest. Host defenses: (1) Egg recognition and rejection — hosts learn their own egg appearance and reject foreign eggs (ejecting or puncturing them). (2) Nest desertion — abandoning parasitized nests. (3) Mobbing — aggressive attack of adult cuckoos near the nest. (4) Chick recognition — some hosts (superb fairy-wrens) teach embryos a password call that chicks must produce to be fed. The evolutionary outcome depends on the costs and benefits of each strategy. Some hosts (dunnocks) show no egg rejection despite heavy parasitism — possibly because they have not yet evolved recognition, or because the costs of recognition errors (accidentally rejecting own eggs) are too high.

questions.question: Fisher's runaway sexual selection model explains the evolution of exaggerated male ornaments. How does the runaway process work?
options: In Fisher's model, a positive feedback loop develops between female preference genes and male trait genes — if females with a preference gene mate with ornamented males, their sons inherit the ornament AND their daughters inherit the preference, creating genetic correlation (linkage disequilibrium) between trait and preference; this self-reinforcing cycle drives both trait and preference to increasingly extreme values until opposed by natural selection costs
Runaway selection produces ornaments that always reduce male survival without any female preference
The process requires group selection to maintain female preferences
Runaway selection only affects body size, not visual ornaments
questions.explanation: R.A. Fisher (1930) proposed the runaway process, later formalized mathematically by Lande (1981) and Kirkpatrick (1982). The mechanism: (1) Initial condition: Some males have a slightly exaggerated trait (e.g., longer tails) that provides a genuine viability advantage (e.g., better aerodynamics) or signals condition. Some females have a preference for this trait. (2) Genetic correlation: Females with the preference gene preferentially mate with males carrying the trait gene. Because Mendelian inheritance combines parental alleles, offspring inherit both: sons carry the trait gene and daughters carry the preference gene. This creates linkage disequilibrium (non-random association) between the two loci. (3) Positive feedback: Ornamented males produce daughters with the preference, who produce ornamented sons — the preference is self-reinforcing because choosing ornamented males increases the attractiveness of sons (sexy sons hypothesis). (4) Runaway: As the preference spreads, the trait becomes more extreme because more females prefer it. As the trait becomes more extreme, the preference intensifies because the benefit of having attractive sons increases. This creates an accelerating feedback loop. (5) Equilibrium: The runaway process is eventually halted when the survival cost of the exaggerated trait equals the mating advantage. The result is a stable equilibrium where the trait is more elaborate than the natural-selection optimum. Key predictions: (a) The genetic correlation between trait and preference should be detectable (confirmed in stalk-eyed flies). (b) Removing the ornament should reduce mating success but increase survival. (c) The process can maintain traits with NO honest signaling function — the ornament is arbitrary. This distinguishes runaway from the handicap/good-genes model.

questions.question: Altruistic punishment refers to the costly enforcement of cooperative norms. How does it promote cooperation in groups?
options: Altruistic punishment occurs when individuals pay a personal cost to punish free-riders who fail to cooperate — this deters cheating and stabilizes cooperation in larger groups where reciprocal altruism alone is insufficient; experimental evidence from public goods games shows that cooperation collapses without punishment but is maintained when participants can pay to reduce the payoff of free-riders, even in one-shot anonymous interactions where direct reciprocity is impossible
Punishment always reduces cooperation by creating hostile social environments
Altruistic punishment occurs only in humans and has no analogue in other species
Free-riders are never punished in any natural system
questions.explanation: Altruistic punishment (Fehr and Gachter 2002) is a key mechanism for maintaining cooperation in large groups where repeated interactions and reputation are insufficient: (1) The cooperation problem: In public goods scenarios, the rational individual strategy is to free-ride (benefit from others' contributions without paying). This leads to the 'tragedy of the commons' where cooperation collapses. (2) Punishment as a solution: If cooperators can punish defectors (at a cost to themselves), the expected cost of free-riding exceeds the benefit, deterring cheating. The punishment is 'altruistic' because the punisher pays a cost to benefit the group. (3) Experimental evidence: Fehr and Gachter's public goods game with punishment: when participants can spend money to reduce free-riders' earnings, cooperation stabilizes at high levels. Without punishment, cooperation declines to near zero over rounds. This occurs even in one-shot, anonymous games where reputation effects and future reciprocity are excluded. (4) Evolution of punishment: How can costly punishment evolve if punishers bear the cost? Possible explanations: (a) Strong reciprocity — a bundle of cooperative tendencies including punishment that coevolved with human ultrasociality. (b) Second-order free-rider problem — who punishes the non-punishers? Solved if punishment is cheap relative to the cooperation benefit, or if non-punishers are also punished. (c) Cultural group selection — groups with punishers outcompete groups without. (5) Animal examples: Cleaner fish clients punish cheating cleaners by chasing them; dominant meerkats punish subordinates that attempt to breed; policing in social insects (workers destroy eggs laid by other workers, maintaining queen monopoly on reproduction).

questions.question: The greenbeard effect is a theoretical mechanism for altruism that does not require kinship. What are its three necessary components?
options: A greenbeard gene must produce three effects: (1) a recognizable phenotypic tag (the 'green beard'), (2) the ability to recognize the same tag in others, and (3) altruistic behavior directed specifically toward individuals bearing the tag — this allows a gene to spread by helping copies of itself in other individuals regardless of overall relatedness; the fire ant Gp-9 gene and the csA gene in Dictyostelium social amoebae are candidate examples
The greenbeard effect requires all three components: green coloration, facial hair, and aggressive behavior
Greenbeard genes only need to produce a visible tag; recognition and altruism are provided by separate genes
The greenbeard effect has been proven impossible and no real examples exist
questions.explanation: The greenbeard concept (named by Dawkins 1976, based on Hamilton's 1964 suggestion) describes a single gene (or tightly linked gene complex) that: (1) Produces a recognizable phenotype — a conspicuous marker ('green beard') that identifies carriers to each other. (2) Enables recognition — carriers can detect the marker in other individuals. (3) Directs altruism — carriers behave altruistically toward other individuals bearing the marker. This bypasses the need for kinship: the gene helps copies of itself directly, regardless of genome-wide relatedness. Hamilton's rule still applies but r refers to the probability of sharing the greenbeard allele specifically, not average genome relatedness. Real candidates: (a) Fire ant Gp-9 gene (Keller and Ross 2004): Workers carrying the Gp-9b allele kill queens that lack it (i.e., are homozygous Gp-9B/Gp-9B). The Gp-9b allele affects cuticular hydrocarbon profiles (the phenotypic tag), recognition of that profile, and the killing behavior. (b) FLO1 gene in yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae): Produces a cell-surface flocculin protein (tag) that causes cells to aggregate preferentially with other FLO1+ cells (recognition + cooperation through group protection). (c) csA gene in Dictyostelium discoideum: Encodes a cell adhesion molecule; csA+ cells preferentially aggregate with other csA+ cells during fruiting body formation, gaining a fitness advantage. Challenges: Greenbeard genes are vulnerable to 'falsebeards' — cheaters that display the tag but do not cooperate. This creates selection for increasingly specific recognition mechanisms. Most proposed greenbeard genes involve linked gene complexes rather than single genes with pleiotropic effects.

questions.question: Animal cognition research investigates mental processes in non-human animals. What evidence suggests that some animals possess theory of mind?
options: Theory of mind (ToM) — the ability to attribute mental states to others — has been suggested in chimpanzees and corvids: (1) chimpanzees in competitive food paradigms preferentially approach food hidden from a dominant's view, suggesting they understand what the dominant can and cannot see; (2) scrub-jays that have stolen food caches re-cache their food when observed by potential pilferers but not when unobserved, suggesting they attribute knowledge/intentions to observers; however, these results remain debated because simpler behavioral rule explanations cannot be fully excluded
No animal species shows any evidence of understanding other individuals' mental states
Only dolphins have theory of mind; all other animals lack this ability
Theory of mind requires human language and is therefore impossible in non-verbal species
questions.explanation: Theory of mind (Premack and Woodruff 1978) is one of the most intensely debated topics in comparative cognition. Evidence: (1) Chimpanzees — competitive paradigms: Hare et al. (2000, 2001) placed food between a subordinate and a dominant chimpanzee. When the food was visible to both, the subordinate avoided it. When the food was hidden behind a barrier visible only from the subordinate's side, the subordinate approached it. This suggests the subordinate understands the dominant's visual perspective. (2) Chimpanzees — helping: Chimpanzees hand a human an out-of-reach object the human is reaching for, even when the object is of no value to the chimp — suggesting understanding of the human's goal/desire. (3) Western scrub-jays (Clayton and colleagues): Jays that have personally experienced pilfering others' caches take anti-pilfering measures (re-caching when observed, moving caches to new locations after being watched). Jays that have never stolen others' caches do not re-cache. This 'experience projection' — attributing one's own knowledge to others — is a component of ToM. (4) False belief test: The gold standard for ToM in children (Sally-Anne task). Results in great apes are mixed and controversial. Krupenye et al. (2016) used eye-tracking to show that apes look anticipatorily toward where a human will search based on the human's false belief, but whether this represents true belief attribution or learned behavioral prediction remains debated. The central challenge: Morgan's canon (prefer the simplest explanation) means behavioral-rule explanations (learned associations between cues and outcomes) must be excluded before inferring mental-state attribution. This is methodologically extremely difficult.

questions.question: Play behavior is widespread in juvenile mammals and some birds. What are the proposed adaptive functions of play?
options: Play behavior (locomotor play, object play, social play) is hypothesized to serve multiple functions: (1) motor training — practicing and refining movement patterns used in adult hunting, fighting, and escape (predatory play sequences in kittens resemble adult hunting); (2) social skill development — learning dominance relationships, cooperation, and communication rules; (3) cognitive development — enhancing behavioral flexibility and innovation through exploration; (4) physical conditioning — developing cardiovascular and musculoskeletal fitness; the 'training for the unexpected' hypothesis suggests play promotes adaptive responses to novel situations
Play behavior has no adaptive function and is purely a waste of energy
Play occurs only in domesticated animals and never in wild populations
Play behavior is identical to adult aggression with no distinguishing features
questions.explanation: Play behavior (Burghardt 2005; Pellis and Pellis 2009) is defined by five criteria: (1) Not fully functional in the context performed. (2) Spontaneous, voluntary, and pleasurable. (3) Differs structurally or temporally from serious behavior (exaggerated movements, role reversals). (4) Performed repeatedly. (5) Occurs when the animal is healthy, well-fed, and unstressed. Categories: (a) Locomotor/rotational play — running, jumping, spinning (seen in young ungulates, primates, corvids). (b) Object play — manipulating objects without a clear functional goal (otters with stones, dolphins with bubbles). (c) Social play — play fighting, chasing, wrestling with conspecifics (includes self-handicapping, role reversal, play signals like the canid play bow). Hypothesized functions: (1) Motor training: Practice refines neuromuscular coordination. Juvenile rats deprived of play have less developed motor cortex and are poorer at adult social behaviors. Kittens' play sequences contain elements of adult hunting (stalk, pounce, bite). (2) Social competence: Play fighting teaches bite inhibition, reading social signals, negotiation of dominance, and cooperation. Animals deprived of social play (isolation-reared) show social deficits as adults. (3) Cognitive flexibility: Spinka et al.'s (2001) 'training for the unexpected' hypothesis suggests play deliberately creates unpredictable situations (loss of balance, unexpected partner responses), training the brain to cope with sudden changes — enhancing behavioral flexibility. (4) Physical conditioning: Play provides cardiovascular exercise during development. The costs of play (energy expenditure ~2-15% of daily budget, risk of injury ~0.5-5% of play sessions, increased predation risk) suggest the benefits must be substantial for play to be maintained by selection.

questions.question: Hormones modulate behavior across vertebrates. What role does testosterone play in aggressive and reproductive behavior?
options: Testosterone is an androgenic steroid produced primarily by the testes (Leydig cells) that has organizational effects during development (permanently structuring neural circuits, e.g., sexually dimorphic nucleus of the preoptic area) and activational effects in adults (reversibly modulating behavior); it promotes territorial aggression, courtship displays, and dominance behavior — Wingfield's challenge hypothesis predicts that testosterone rises in response to social challenges (territorial intrusions, mate competition) rather than staying chronically elevated, because sustained high testosterone suppresses immune function and parental care
Testosterone has no effect on animal behavior and only affects physical growth
Testosterone levels are always constant and never respond to social context
Only mammals produce testosterone; birds and reptiles use entirely different hormones for aggression
questions.explanation: Testosterone (T) is a central hormone in behavioral endocrinology, with both organizational and activational effects: Organizational effects (during development): (a) Sexual differentiation of the brain — in mammals, prenatal T exposure masculinizes brain structures including the sexually dimorphic nucleus of the preoptic area (SDN-POA, larger in males), bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, and amygdala. (b) These structural differences underlie sex-typical behavioral patterns in adulthood. (c) In birds, estrogen (aromatized from T) is the primary masculinizing hormone for brain sexual differentiation. Activational effects (in adults): (a) Aggression — T facilitates territorial aggression in most vertebrates. Castrated male birds reduce territorial singing and aggression; T implants restore it. (b) Courtship — T drives courtship displays, singing (in songbirds, T stimulates HVC and RA song nuclei), and mating behavior. (c) Dominance — T often correlates with social rank, though causality is bidirectional (winning fights increases T). The challenge hypothesis (Wingfield et al. 1990): In seasonally breeding birds, T rises to breeding baseline levels during the reproductive season but spikes further only during social challenges (territorial intrusions, mate guarding). This explains why: (a) Species with frequent challenges (polygynous, colonial) have higher T. (b) Species with extensive paternal care have lower baseline T (high T suppresses paternal behavior). (c) Chronic high T is costly: immunosuppression (via reduced lymphocyte function), increased metabolic rate, and greater predation risk from conspicuous behavior. The immunocompetence handicap hypothesis (Folstad and Karter 1992) connects T to honest signaling: T promotes ornament expression but suppresses immunity, so only healthy males can afford high T.

questions.question:
Match the following anti-predator strategies with their descriptions:
(I) Aposematism
(II) Mullerian mimicry
(III) Crypsis
(IV) Startle display

(P) Two or more unpalatable species evolve similar warning coloration, sharing the cost of predator education and reducing per-capita mortality from sampling
(Q) Sudden display of conspicuous features (eyespots, bright colors, sounds) when threatened, causing predator hesitation and providing escape time
(R) Matching body color, shape, and behavior to the background, reducing detection probability by visual predators
(S) Conspicuous warning coloration (bright colors, high contrast patterns) advertising unprofitability (toxicity, venom, bad taste) to visual predators that learn to avoid the signal
options: I-S, II-P, III-R, IV-Q
I-R, II-Q, III-S, IV-P
I-P, II-S, III-Q, IV-R
I-Q, II-R, III-P, IV-S
questions.explanation: Aposematism (I-S): Warning coloration signals to potential predators that the prey is dangerous, toxic, or unpalatable. Features: bright, conspicuous colors (red, orange, yellow, often with black), high contrast patterns, and often coupled with gregarious behavior (amplifying the signal). Examples: poison dart frogs (Dendrobatidae) with alkaloid toxins, coral snakes with neurotoxic venom, monarch butterflies with cardiac glycosides from milkweed. Predators learn through one-trial or few-trial aversive experiences to avoid the signal. Mullerian mimicry (II-P): Fritz Muller (1879) showed that two or more genuinely unpalatable species benefit from converging on the same warning pattern. The selective advantage: predators need only learn one pattern to avoid all species sharing it, reducing the number of prey killed during predator education. The per-capita cost of 'educating' naive predators is shared among all mimicry ring members. Examples: various neotropical Heliconius butterfly species share wing patterns in local mimicry rings. Crypsis (III-R): Background matching through color, pattern, body shape, and behavior. Types include: (a) General background matching (peppered moth Biston betularia). (b) Disruptive coloration — high-contrast patterns that break up the body outline. (c) Countershading — darker dorsal, lighter ventral surface, eliminating the shadow that reveals 3D shape. (d) Masquerade — resembling an inedible object (stick insects, leaf-mimicking katydids). Many cryptic species also use behavioral crypsis (remaining motionless, aligning with background patterns). Startle display (IV-Q): Deimatic behavior — sudden revelation of hidden conspicuous features when a predator approaches. Examples: owl butterfly hindwing eyespots, praying mantis threat display (spreading forelegs to reveal bright patches), hawkmoth caterpillar inflating 'snake-head' thorax. The momentary startle buys time for escape. Most effective against naive or cautious predators.

questions.question: Nuptial gifts are resources transferred from one sex (usually males) to the other during courtship or mating. What is their adaptive significance?
options: Nuptial gifts serve multiple functions: (1) female mate-choice criterion — females prefer males offering larger or higher-quality gifts (hangingflies Hylobittacus select males based on prey size); (2) paternity assurance — males that provide larger gifts achieve longer copulations and transfer more sperm (in scorpionflies and bushcrickets); (3) nutrient provisioning — gifts provide essential nutrients for egg production, directly increasing female fecundity; however, sexual conflict exists because some males offer worthless gifts (salivary secretion balls wrapped in silk in nursery-web spiders) and some female katydids consume the spermatophylax before all sperm are transferred
Nuptial gifts are purely decorative and have no fitness consequences
Only insects produce nuptial gifts; vertebrates never transfer resources during mating
Nuptial gifts always decrease male fitness without any compensating benefit
questions.explanation: Nuptial gifts (Vahed 1998, Lewis and South 2012) are widespread in insects, spiders, and some birds: Types of nuptial gifts: (a) Prey items — male scorpionflies (Panorpa) and hangingflies (Bittacus) capture arthropod prey and present them to females during courtship. In Hylobittacus apicalis, females accept mating only if the prey exceeds a minimum size (~16 mm²); copulation duration and sperm transfer increase with prey size. (b) Spermatophylax — a protein-rich, non-sperm portion of the spermatophore in bushcrickets (Tettigoniidae) and Mormon crickets (Anabrus simplex). The female eats the spermatophylax while sperm transfer occurs from the attached sperm ampulla. Males benefit because the longer the female takes to eat the gift, the more sperm are transferred. (c) Glandular secretions — male fireflies (Photinus) transfer seminal gifts with nutrients and defensive compounds (lucibufagins). Male bushcrickets produce gifts constituting up to 40% of body mass. (d) Nuptial feeding in birds — male terns offer fish to females during courtship, signaling foraging ability. Adaptive functions: (1) Mate attraction and acceptance — females preferentially mate with gift-giving males. (2) Extended copulation — gift consumption occupies the female, allowing more sperm transfer. (3) Direct nutritional benefit — nutrients in gifts are incorporated into eggs, increasing clutch size. (4) Manipulation/deception — some males offer worthless gifts: male nursery-web spiders (Pisaura mirabilis) sometimes wrap inedible items in silk; females that detect the deception terminate mating sooner. Sexual conflict: The spermatophylax represents a conflict — males benefit from maximal sperm transfer, but females may benefit from eating the spermatophylax quickly (gaining nutrients) and re-mating with another male sooner. In some katydids, spermatophylax size has increased evolutionarily as a male counter-adaptation to female consumption speed.

questions.question: Behavioral polyphenism occurs when the same genotype produces different behavioral phenotypes depending on environmental conditions. What is a well-studied example?
options: Desert locusts (Schistocerca gregaria) exhibit a dramatic behavioral polyphenism: low-density conditions produce the solitary (solitaria) phase — cryptic green/brown coloration, low activity, avoidance of conspecifics; high-density crowding triggers the gregarious (gregaria) phase — conspicuous black-and-yellow coloration, high activity, attraction to conspecifics, and migratory swarming behavior; the phase transition is mediated by serotonin signaling in the thoracic ganglia, triggered by tactile stimulation of the hind legs during crowding
Behavioral polyphenism does not exist; all behavior is genetically fixed
Only plants show polyphenism; animals always express the same phenotype
Polyphenism refers to having multiple genes, not multiple phenotypes
questions.explanation: Locust phase polyphenism (Pener and Simpson 2009, Rogers et al. 2003) is one of the most dramatic examples of environmentally induced behavioral change: Solitaria phase (low density): (a) Cryptic coloration (green/brown). (b) Avoidance of conspecifics. (c) Low locomotor activity. (d) Solitary foraging. (e) No migratory behavior. Gregaria phase (high density): (a) Aposematic coloration (black-and-yellow). (b) Strong attraction to conspecifics (aggregation). (c) High locomotor activity and marching behavior. (d) Formation of massive migratory swarms (billions of individuals covering 100+ km²). (e) Polyphagy (broader diet). The transition mechanism: (1) Tactile stimulation — crowding increases physical contact, particularly stimulation of mechanoreceptors on the hind femora (back legs). This is the primary proximate trigger. (2) Serotonin — Anstey et al. (2009) showed that serotonin levels in the thoracic ganglia increase within hours of crowding. Serotonin injection into solitary locusts induces gregarious behavior. Serotonin synthesis inhibitors block the phase change. (3) The transition involves epigenetic changes (DNA methylation, histone modification) that alter gene expression across hundreds of genes affecting nervous system, metabolism, and pigmentation. (4) Maternal effects — gregarious mothers produce gregarious offspring even in isolation (trans-generational effects mediated by egg gregarizing factor). Other examples: (a) Honey bee castes — queen vs. worker is a nutritional polyphenism (royal jelly diet triggers queen development). (b) Aphid wing polyphenism — crowding induces winged (alate) morphs that disperse. (c) Daphnia defensive morphology — predator chemical cues induce helmets and neck spines.

questions.question: A behavioral ecologist hypothesizes that meerkats (Suricata suricatta) teach their pups how to handle dangerous prey (scorpions). What observations and experiments would distinguish teaching from other forms of social learning?
options: Observe that adults bring dead scorpions to very young pups, disabled (stingless) scorpions to older pups, and live scorpions to near-independent juveniles

Conduct a cross-fostering experiment and measure adult behavior modification based on pup age: demonstrate that (1) adults modify their behavior only in the presence of pups (not when alone), (2) the difficulty of prey provided is calibrated to pup age/competence (dead → disabled → live scorpions), (3) adults pay a cost (lost foraging time, risk of scorpion stings while disabling prey), (4) pups learn faster with adults present than without — meeting Caro and Hauser's (1992) definition of teaching: the tutor modifies its behavior in the presence of a naive observer at a cost to itself, facilitating learning in the observer
Simply count how many scorpions pups eat per day
Compare scorpion consumption between meerkat populations in different habitats
questions.explanation: Teaching in animals (Caro and Hauser 1992, Thornton and McAuliffe 2006) is rigorously defined by three criteria: (1) The tutor modifies its behavior ONLY in the presence of naive individuals (not performing the same behavior when alone or with experienced individuals). (2) The modification is costly to the tutor (time, energy, or risk). (3) The modification results in faster or more efficient learning by the pupil. Thornton and McAuliffe (2006) demonstrated teaching in meerkats: Observations: (a) Helper meerkats bring prey items to pups, with the difficulty graded by pup age: very young pups (~30 days) receive dead scorpions; older pups (~60 days) receive disabled scorpions (stinger removed by biting); near-independent pups (~90 days) receive intact live scorpions. (b) Helpers were observed nudging escaped prey back toward pups. (c) This graduated curriculum was not random — playback experiments using young pup begging calls caused helpers to bring easier prey, while older pup calls elicited harder prey. Experimental tests: (a) Playback manipulation: By broadcasting begging calls of different-aged pups, researchers showed that helpers adjust prey difficulty in response to perceived pup age (ruling out direct assessment of pup competence). (b) Cost documentation: Helpers spent time disabling prey and sometimes lost prey items while demonstrating handling. (c) Learning outcome: Pups exposed to the graduated curriculum developed scorpion-handling skills faster. This study provided the first experimentally supported case of teaching in a wild non-human animal, meeting all three of Caro and Hauser's criteria. Other proposed examples: tandem running in ants (Temnothorax), vocal tutoring in superb fairy-wrens (embryonic call teaching).

questions.question: The producer-scrounger game models foraging decisions when individuals can either search for food independently (produce) or exploit the discoveries of others (scrounge). What does the model predict?
options: The producer-scrounger model predicts a frequency-dependent equilibrium: if most individuals produce, scrounging is profitable (easy to find producers' discoveries); if most scrounge, producing is profitable (fewer scroungers per discovery) — the equilibrium frequency of producers and scroungers depends on group size, patch divisibility, and the 'finder's share' (the portion of a discovered patch the producer can consume before scroungers arrive); compatible scrounging (joining) coexists with producing in a stable equilibrium
All group members should always produce and never scrounge
Scrounging is always more profitable than producing regardless of frequency
The model applies only to human economic behavior, not to animal foraging
questions.explanation: The producer-scrounger (PS) game (Barnard and Sibly 1981, Vickery et al. 1991, Giraldeau and Caraco 2000) applies frequency-dependent game theory to social foraging: The setup: In a group of N foragers, each individual at every opportunity can either: (a) Produce — search independently for food, paying a search cost, and discovering patches at some rate. (b) Scrounge — do not search independently but instead exploit (join) patches discovered by producers. Frequency dependence: If S = number of scroungers and P = number of producers (P + S = N): (a) Producer payoff: proportional to P (fewer competing searchers, more likely to find food) but decreasing in S (more scroungers join each discovery). (b) Scrounger payoff: proportional to P (more producers = more discoveries to exploit) but decreasing in S (more scroungers compete at each discovery). At equilibrium: producer and scrounger payoffs are equal, and neither strategy can invade the other. Key parameters: (1) Finder's share (a) — the proportion of a discovered patch that the producer can consume before scroungers arrive. Higher finder's share favors producing. If a = 1 (producer consumes everything), no scrounging. If a = 0 (all food shared equally), only scrounging. (2) Group size — larger groups favor scrounging because more producers create more opportunities. (3) Patch divisibility — easily shared patches favor scrounging; monopolizable patches favor producing. Experimental evidence: House sparrows in flocks: some individuals consistently produce while others scrounge. Scrounger frequency increases with group size and decreases with finder's share (e.g., increasing inter-seed distance in grid experiments). Dominant individuals often scrounge more (they can displace producers from patches). The PS game predicts that obligate scrounging reduces group foraging efficiency because scroungers contribute nothing to search effort — a social foraging version of the free-rider problem.

questions.question: Lek mating systems present a paradox: females choose among males that provide no resources or parental care. What hypotheses explain the evolution and maintenance of leks?
options: Several hypotheses explain lek evolution: (1) hotspot model — males aggregate at locations where female movement patterns intersect, maximizing encounter rates; (2) hotshot model — subordinate males cluster around attractive dominant males to intercept females attracted to the hotshot; (3) female preference model — females prefer to mate at aggregations because it facilitates comparison of males and reduces per-capita harassment; the lek paradox (females consistently choose certain males, yet genetic variance should be depleted) is partially resolved by condition-dependent expression and genic capture
Leks form purely by random aggregation with no adaptive explanation
Males on leks defend food territories that attract females
Lek mating is always monogamous with each male mating with exactly one female
questions.explanation: Leks (Hoglund and Alatalo 1995) are aggregations of displaying males where females visit primarily to mate, and males provide no parental care or resources beyond sperm. Examples: sage grouse, birds-of-paradise, peacocks, many tropical manakins, Uganda kob, hammer-headed bats. Features: (a) Extreme sexual selection — typically 10-20% of males achieve 70-90% of matings. (b) Pronounced sexual dimorphism — males are highly ornamented. Hypotheses for lek formation: (1) Hotspot model (Bradbury 1981): Males settle at locations where female home ranges overlap ('hotspots'), maximizing the number of females encountered. Prediction: lek location should correlate with female density or movement patterns. (2) Hotshot model (Beehler and Foster 1988): Less attractive males cluster around a highly attractive 'hotshot' male, intercepting some females attracted by the hotshot. Prediction: removing the hotshot should cause the cluster to dissolve or reform around the next most attractive male. (3) Female preference model (Bradbury 1981): Females prefer to mate at larger aggregations because: (a) easier comparison of multiple males, (b) reduced predation risk during mate assessment, (c) reduced per-capita harassment from males. The lek paradox (Kirkpatrick and Ryan 1991): Strong directional female choice should deplete additive genetic variance in male quality, yet females continue to show preferences. Resolutions: (a) Condition-dependent expression — ornament expression depends on environmental and genetic quality across many loci (genic capture). (b) Mutation-selection balance — harmful mutations continuously introduce genetic variance. (c) Fluctuating selection — varying environmental pressures maintain genetic diversity. (d) Genotype-by-environment interactions — no single genotype is best in all conditions.

questions.question: Researchers study oxytocin's role in social bonding by comparing prairie voles (monogamous) and montane voles (polygamous). They find that prairie voles have high densities of oxytocin receptors (OTR) in the nucleus accumbens and prefrontal cortex, while montane voles have low OTR density in these regions. When OTR is virally overexpressed in the nucleus accumbens of montane voles, they show increased partner preference. What does this demonstrate?
options: This demonstrates that the neural distribution of oxytocin receptors, rather than the amount of oxytocin itself, determines species differences in social bonding behavior — the nucleus accumbens is part of the dopaminergic reward pathway, and OTR expression there links social interaction with reward, creating partner-specific attachment; this is a proximate mechanism (Tinbergen's causation level) explaining behavioral differences between species through receptor expression patterns rather than differences in the neuropeptide itself
Oxytocin has no role in social bonding and the results are coincidental
Prairie voles and montane voles have identical brain chemistry
The results show that all mammals with oxytocin must be monogamous
questions.explanation: The prairie vole (Microtus ochrogaster) / montane vole (Microtus montanus) comparison (Young et al. 1999, Lim et al. 2004) is a landmark study in behavioral neuroendocrinology demonstrating how receptor distribution patterns create behavioral differences: The system: Prairie voles are socially monogamous — forming long-term pair bonds, sharing a nest, biparental care, and selective aggression toward unfamiliar conspecifics after bonding. Montane voles are promiscuous — no pair bonds, females raise pups alone. Key findings: (1) Oxytocin receptor (OTR) distribution: Prairie voles have high OTR density in the nucleus accumbens (NAcc, reward center) and prefrontal cortex (PFC, decision-making). Montane voles have low OTR in these regions but similar levels elsewhere. (2) Vasopressin receptor (V1aR) distribution: Prairie vole males have high V1aR in the ventral pallidum (reward-related region). Montane voles have low V1aR there. (3) Viral vector experiments (Lim et al. 2004): Injecting a viral vector expressing the V1aR gene into the ventral pallidum of montane voles increased partner preference and pair-bonding behavior. Similarly, increasing OTR in the NAcc enhanced social bonding. (4) Mechanism: Mating releases oxytocin (females) and vasopressin (males). When receptors are present in reward circuitry (NAcc/ventral pallidum), the social stimulus (partner) becomes associated with dopamine-mediated reward. This creates a conditioned partner preference — essentially, the brain 'rewards' the animal for being with its specific partner. (5) Genetic basis: The V1aR gene (avpr1a) has a microsatellite repeat in its promoter in prairie voles but not montane voles. The repeat length affects receptor expression levels in the brain. This illustrates how a regulatory genetic change (not a protein-coding change) can produce major behavioral differences between closely related species.

questions.question: Taxis and kinesis are simple orientation behaviors. What distinguishes a taxis from a kinesis?
options: A taxis is a directed movement toward or away from a stimulus (positive or negative phototaxis, chemotaxis, geotaxis), involving orientation of the body axis relative to the stimulus source — a kinesis is an undirected response where the rate of movement (orthokinesis) or rate of turning (klinokinesis) changes with stimulus intensity, resulting in aggregation in favorable conditions without directional orientation; for example, woodlice show klinokinesis to humidity — they turn more frequently in dry areas and less in humid areas, accumulating in moist microhabitats
Taxis and kinesis are identical terms for the same behavior
A kinesis involves directed movement while a taxis is random
Both taxis and kinesis require learning and do not occur in invertebrates
questions.explanation: Taxis and kinesis represent two fundamental orientation strategies, differing in whether the animal orients its body relative to the stimulus: Taxis (directed orientation): (1) Positive taxis — movement toward the stimulus. Positive phototaxis in moths approaching light (though the mechanism is actually a navigational error related to transverse orientation to distant light sources). Positive chemotaxis in bacteria swimming up chemical gradients. (2) Negative taxis — movement away from the stimulus. Negative phototaxis in cockroaches fleeing light. Negative geotaxis in fly larvae climbing upward. (3) Types by mechanism: (a) Klinotaxis — comparison of stimulus intensity over time by swinging the head side to side (Drosophila larvae navigating odor gradients). (b) Tropotaxis — simultaneous comparison of stimulus intensity at two bilateral sensors (planarian orientation toward light using paired eyespots). (c) Telotaxis — orientation directly toward the stimulus using a single sensor (bee flying toward a food source). Kinesis (undirected response): (1) Orthokinesis — movement speed changes with stimulus intensity. Planaria move faster in bright light, slower in dim light, accumulating in dark areas. (2) Klinokinesis — turning rate changes with stimulus intensity. Woodlice (Porcellio scaber) turn more frequently in dry conditions and less in humid conditions. Over time, they aggregate in humid microhabitats — not because they detect the direction to moisture, but because they effectively get 'trapped' in favorable areas (high turning in bad areas + low turning in good areas = accumulation). The adaptive value of kinesis is that it requires minimal neural processing — no directional computation needed — making it effective for animals with simple nervous systems navigating simple gradients.

questions.question: Tool use was once considered uniquely human, but it has been documented in several animal taxa. What is the most sophisticated non-primate tool use observed in the wild?
options: New Caledonian crows (Corvus moneduloides) manufacture and use multiple tool types: they fashion hooked stick tools by snapping twigs and trimming them into hooks, and create stepped pandanus-leaf tools by making a series of precisely spaced rips and cuts in pandanus leaves — tool designs vary regionally (cultural traditions), juvenile crows learn tool techniques through extended observation of parents, and crows modify tools to improve their function (meta-tool use: using one tool to retrieve another tool)
No animal outside of primates has ever been observed using tools
Tool use in birds is always accidental and never involves tool manufacture
Only captive animals use tools; wild animals never do
questions.explanation: New Caledonian crows (Hunt 1996, Hunt and Gray 2003, Taylor et al. 2007) demonstrate the most sophisticated tool manufacture outside of great apes: Tool types: (1) Hooked stick tools — crows select live twigs of appropriate length and flexibility, strip off leaves, and fashion a hook at one end by working the twig against a branch. The hook enables extraction of grubs from wood holes and crevices. (2) Stepped pandanus-leaf tools — crows make a series of tears and cuts in the tough leaves of pandanus trees, creating a tapered, stepped strip tool. The stepped design varies among regions, suggesting cultural transmission of tool designs (analogous to human material culture). (3) Thorn tools — using cactus spines as probes. Cognitive sophistication: (a) Metatool use — in laboratory experiments, crows use a short tool to retrieve a longer tool, which they then use to access food (sequential tool use requiring planning). (b) Causal reasoning — experiments show crows can infer the correct tool for a novel task without trial-and-error (e.g., selecting tools of appropriate length). (c) Future planning — crows carry favored tools between foraging sites, suggesting they anticipate future need. (d) Manufacture precision — the angular cuts in pandanus-leaf tools follow species-specific 'designs' transmitted socially across generations. Other notable animal tool users: (a) Chimpanzees — termite fishing, nut cracking with stone/wood anvils and hammers, leaf sponges. (b) Bottlenose dolphins — using marine sponges on the rostrum to protect against abrasion while foraging on the sea floor ('sponging,' Mann et al. 2008). (c) Egyptian vultures — dropping stones on ostrich eggs. (d) Sea otters — using rocks as anvils to break open shellfish. (e) Archerfish — using jets of water as tools to knock insects from vegetation.

questions.question: Supernormal stimuli are exaggerated versions of natural sign stimuli that elicit stronger-than-normal behavioral responses. What is a classic example, and what does it reveal about sensory processing?
options: Tinbergen demonstrated that herring gulls preferentially peck at artificial oversized eggs with exaggerated spots over their own normal eggs, and that oystercatchers attempt to incubate giant artificial eggs rather than their own — this reveals that animal nervous systems respond to specific stimulus features (key stimuli) with open-ended response functions that do not plateau at normal intensity, suggesting that natural signals have not evolved to maximally stimulate receivers, possibly constrained by other selection pressures like predator detection
Animals never respond to artificial stimuli that differ from natural ones
Supernormal stimuli have only been demonstrated in laboratory conditions and have no ecological relevance
All animals have a fixed upper threshold and cannot respond more strongly to exaggerated stimuli
questions.explanation: Supernormal stimuli (Tinbergen 1951) provide fundamental insights into how animal nervous systems process sensory information: Classic examples: (1) Herring gull chick pecking: Chicks peck at the red spot on the parent's bill to solicit regurgitation. Tinbergen and Perdeck (1950) showed that a thin red rod with three white bands (supernormal stimulus) elicits more pecking than a realistic gull bill model. The chick's neural system responds to specific features (contrast, length, redness) with a monotonically increasing response function. (2) Egg retrieval: Oystercatchers presented with a choice between their own egg and a giant artificial egg attempt to incubate the giant egg. Greylag geese similarly prefer oversized eggs. (3) Stickleback aggression: Males show more intense aggression toward models with exaggerated red undersides than toward realistic models. (4) Reed warbler cuckoo chick: Cuckoo chicks have an exceptionally wide, brightly colored gape that supernormally stimulates host feeding behavior — host parents preferentially feed the cuckoo over their own chicks. What this reveals: (a) Animal sensory/perceptual systems are tuned to specific stimulus features (sign stimuli or key stimuli) rather than holistic perception.
